passages.text: August 29, 2025 03:10 PM GMT
This week, Jens Eisenschmidt and Chiara Zangarelli discuss lessons from Japan's population decline. Next week, the focus will be on EA inflation and the UK's DMP survey.

While the economics team is back from vacations, markets are still not back in full swing. Data this week was light too. This is the ideal backdrop to take a closer look at what else has been going on. And here the annual Jackson Hole conference (finished last Saturday) caught our attention. Understandably, markets were mainly focussed on what Chair Powell had to say about US monetary policy (our US team revised its call for the Fed funds rate and now sees the cutting cycle starting earlier, see here). But the conference featured other interesting bits as well. The main theme of the conference was on labour markets, a key topic for policy makers (see conference programme here). Among the many great contributions, we found one particularly interesting: the presentation by Governor Ueda from Bank of Japan. Let's dig a bit deeper.

The case of Japan offers a clear picture of what happens in a developed market economy with an ageing and declining population. And this is very interesting because rapidly declining birth rates are a reality in almost all parts of the world and are particularly low in the developed markets (see here). In terms of population dynamics, we all seem destined to look more like Japan, sooner or later. Two key findings from Governor Ueda's presentation are likely to have gotten the most attention. First, labour markets in Japan are so tight now that wages are starting to rise at their fastest pace in decades. Second, it took a big shock - Covid 19 - to change the prevailing equilibrium of low wage increases. Surely, labour markets are tight in Europe too and we also experienced the big Covid 19 shock. So, are we in for a new age of labour market tightness and rapidly rising wages? We don't think so, at least not anytime soon.

The key lies in the less well covered parts of Governor Ueda's presentation. The working age population in Japan had started to decline already in 1995. It took 30 years of decline to generate the labour market tightness that finally led to changes in wage dynamics. The simple reason why it took so long for the labour market tightness to finally show up in wages is that working age population does not equal labour force, and employed persons. There is always some degree of slack in an economy, unemployed persons as well as persons that are not actively seeking employment but could work (inactive side of the population). And here Governor Ueda's presentation gets really interesting. The Japanese economy saw a long process of adjustment, bringing unemployed or inactive resources into work. The labour force participation rate increased since 1995 from 71.6% to 81.6% by 2024, the pension age increased from mid- 60s to upper- 60s and the share of pensioners

Euro Area Inflation | On Track for a September Pause ECB Surveys | Survey of Monetary Analysts France Economics, Equities & Macro Strategy | A Vote on 8 September, and What's Next European Economics Weekly | What Lies Ahead for the EA Economy? Euro Inflation Preview | Services Inflation Continues to Cool Euro Area Macro | PMIs Push The Next Cut to December UK Economics | Some Good News UK Inflation Watch | Steaks on a Plane Nordic Macro Watch | Riksbank | Keeping the Cut in Play Nordic Macro Watch | Norges Bank | Quiet Summer UK GDP | Upside Surprise, Downside Risks UK Labour Market | Another Sluggish Print

working increased too. Finally, Japan opened up somewhat to migration from abroad, even though at a more limited scale than other developed market economies have done.

How does Europe compare? We covered the topic in- depth last year here. The euro area's working age population has been declining since 2010, i.e. by some measures Japan is 15 years ahead of us. While the trend is similar, the difference is in the details. First, the projected decline in Europe's working age population is smaller than what Japan has experienced so far: A \(10\%\) decline until 2050 is projected for Europe vs. \(17\%\) in Japan up until now. Second, the decline in the working age population was uninterrupted in the case of Japan, while the decline in the euro area halted and reversed in 2022 and 2023 (mainly because of Ukrainian refugees). More generally, migration is more important for the European labour market than it is for Japan. For example, net migration represents \(0.4\%\) of the working age population in the euro area vs. \(0.2\%\) in Japan (see here). After all, Japan is an island with a significant language barrier (unlike the UK, for example). And Europe still has many unexploited reservoirs of workers. If we assume the current labour market constellation in Japan as the upper bound, the participation rate in Europe can still rise by another 7pp, freeing up an additional 15 million workers. Likewise, the average retirement age can further increase by seven years in Europe (from 62 years currently to Japan's 69 years). All of this suggests that Europe is not like Japan – and will not be for some time to come. So, the lessons from Japan should not have immediate policy relevance. And sure enough, we expect euro area wages to fall in the coming years – by more than what the ECB currently expects (see here). As a result, inflation is likely to undershoot the ECB's target over the next year (and likely longer). For some time to come, the euro area is more likely to resemble the pre- Covid version of Japan rather than the Japan of today.
